title: Investigating the genetic, social and neuropsychological influences on individual differences in impulsivity & in memory using a lifecourse approach.
abstractText:
The proposed network will bring together researchers from within the social sciences, as well as experts from behavioural genetics, neuropsychology and neuroimaging, and those with an established interest in research ethics.

The aim is to apply ideas and techniques at the cutting edge of behavioural genetics and to capitalise on the research resource represented by the longitudinal British Birth Cohort Studies.

Two substantive areas provide the focus for the network in order to provide tractable questions that can be addressed in the discussions, analysis and pilot work carried out as part of the network activities.

The network will focus on understanding differences in risky and impulsive behaviour among adolescents such as binge drinking, drug taking and unprotected intercourse and will also consider individual differences in memory and learning in mid-life and late middle age and how these relate to experiences and behaviour earlier in the lifecourse. This will allow for an assessment of the feasibility of future interdisciplinary work based around a sub-sample of the Millennium Cohort Study (MCS) and of the 1958 British Birth Cohort Study, known as the National Child Development Study (NCDS).

The aim is to use the exploratory network to develop an interdisciplinary research proposal.
